subject: ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include New Zealand Building Permits, Regional Nikkei Manufacturing PMIs, Japan and China remain closed
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
FOMC

FOMC left the Fed Funds Rate rates unchanged at between 2.25%-2.50% as expected with the decision unanimous, while it cut interest on excess reserves (IOER) by 5bps to 2.35% to keep fed funds rate well within target range. (Newswires)

Fed stated that overall and core inflation have declined on a 12-month basis but added that inflation received since March indicates economic activity has risen at a solid pace and it removed its reference to low inflation being due to energy prices. Fed added job gains have been solid although growth of household spending as well as business and fixed investment have slowed, while it reiterated patience as it determines what future adjustments to rate might be appropriate and are to roll over principal payments from its holding of treasury securities that exceed USD 15bln as previously announced.

Fed Chair Powell commented during the press conference that the change in IOER was technical and not a shift in Fed policy, while he added that a small deviation outside of Fed funds target range would not be important and suggested they could look at the idea of a Repo facility at an upcoming meeting. Furthermore, Powell commented that the inflation drop in early 2019 was unexpected and there might be transitory factors at work, while he does not see case for moving policy in either direction and that the data is not pushing Fed in either direction.

The press conference was viewed as less dovish than some had hoped for as Powell attempted to navigate a neutral line and suggested the IOER was a technical adjustment that does not represent any shift in the Fed's policy stance, while markets also focused on the view that the unexpected decline in core inflation is likely to be transitory. In addition, Powell was pressed on conditions that the Fed would need to see before considering cutting rates but seemed to be reticent to be drawn into the question and instead reiterated the Fed's policy targets. 

 

ASIA-PAC

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and USTR Lighthizer have concluded their 'productive' meetings with China's Vice Premier Liu He, talks are to continue in Washington next week. (Newswires)

A trade deal between US and China is said to be possible by the end of next week, according to sources. Reports noted US and China are said to have neared a deal to roll-back some tariffs which could be announced by the end of next week, while both sides have reached an understanding on how to enforce the agreement although the sources cautioned that details still need to be worked out when a Chinese delegation arrives in Washington on 8 May. Furthermore, reports added there is a general agreement on a plan for the US to immediately remove a 10% tariff on a portion of the USD 200bln worth of Chinese imports affected by the penalty but the USD 50bln tranche of 25% tariffs may remain potentially to after 2020. (Newswires/WSJ/Politico)

UK/EU

UK PM May believes it is possible to achieve a deal with the EU in the second phase of the negotiations before 2020 and that they have shown willingness to compromise on areas of the Withdrawal Agreement. Furthermore, PM May commented there are different ways to approach a future customs union with the EU and suggested what they are trying to achieve for the customs union is similar to Labour’s aims. (Newswires)

UK Labour opposition spokesman stated that we have seen clear evidence that the government are prepared to explore changes in their position on Brexit, while the spokesman added that there will be a full plenary session of cross-party Brexit discussion next week. (Newswires)

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 53.1 vs. Exp. 53.0 (Prev. 55.1). (Newswires) 

 

FX

Canada said they will assist Canola seed farmers impacted by Chinese import ban and will raise the maximum amount of money which can be accessed under the existing farm loan program, while Trade Minister Carr said he will direct a mission to Japan and South Korea early next month in an attempt to increase Canola exports. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 9.934M vs. Exp. 1.485M (Prev. 5.479M). (Newswires)

Oman Oil Minister said the June OPEC meeting will be to extend OPEC cuts and that the oil market will remain balanced even post end of Iranian crude import waivers, while he added USD 70/bbl is an appropriate price for producers and consumers. (Newswires)

Iranian officials agree that its oil sales could fall to 300-400k BPD this Summer (vs. 2.5mln BPD in May 2018), while there were separate reports that officials are said to be discussing potential Iranian scenarios in OPEC including Iran suspending its membership in OPEC until sanctions are removed or even departing from OPEC. (WSJ/Twitter)

Iraq is reportedly planning to boost crude oil exports from its Southern port to 3.45mln BPD. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

A top US General said the focus is on gathering intelligence on the events in Venezuela, but that they are prepared to support the president should he require more from the US Army. (Newswires)

 

US

  • US ISM Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 52.8 vs. Exp. 55.0 (Prev. 55.3). (Newswires)
  • US Markit Manufacturing PMI Final (Apr) 52.6 (Prev. 52.4)
  • US Construction Spending MM (Mar) -0.9% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 1.0%, Rev. 0.7%)
  • US ADP National Employment (Apr) 275k vs. Exp. 180k (Prev. 129k, Rev. 151k)

 

MARKET RECAP

Apple (AAPL) shares jumped higher pre-market after the iPhone maker reported earnings that beat on both top and bottom-line expectations, guided revenue higher for the next quarter and Services revenue hit record highs; boosted dividend, and announced USD 75bln share buyback. L3 Technologies (LLL) rose on strong earnings, the defence technology co. beating analyst expectations for both revenue and profits. Automatic Data Processing (ADP) opened lower after earnings missed on the top and bottom-line expectations. Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) opened higher after the chipmaker also beat analyst expectations on both top and bottom lines. Tesla (TSLA) fell throughout the session, weighed down by the news that the electric automaker would be sued by the family of a driver who had been killed in a Tesla Model X autopilot crash. CVS Health (CVS) shares jumped higher pre-market after the health care services co. reported earnings on both top and bottom lines. Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM) reported strong earnings, beating revenue expectations, but gave away pre-market gains. Humana (HUM) fell after the health insurer announced that it expects earnings to come in below the long-term EPS target of 11-15% in 2020, despite reporting a beat on both top and bottom-line expectations for Q1 19. Home Depot (HD) fell after the company’s CFO of 18 years, Carol Tome, announced her retirement. SPX -0.8% at 2923, NDX -0.4% at 7,752, DJI -0.6% at 26,429.

USTs floundered at the start of the day on thin volumes ahead of the Fed, with modest starting gains surrendered following a better than expected ADP report, with some traders noting a large block flattener of over 13k FVM9s vs over 2K ultra longs. Thereafter, however, ISM manufacturing missed at 52.8 vs. exp. 55 which added upside to the complex, with a large block buyer of 8k USM9 calls noted. The meat of the day, however, was then the Fed’s decision, which saw the curve steepening and treasuries pushing higher, with increased volumes on the front end post the unchanged rate and IOER 5bps cut to 2.35%.  Yields broke the 10th April 2.461% low, but the move was faded after Powell stated the “surprising” inflation prints could be transitory, and the IOER cut was purely “technical”. Thereafter the curve flattened and treasuries slipped to session lows heading into the close. US T-note futures (M9) settled 3 ticks lower at 123-18+.

US MARKET WRAP 1 MAY 2019: FOMC cuts IOER, ISM miss, US/China Trade deal could be announced next week
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities down, dollar up, Treasuries mixed, crude mixed.

* REAR VIEW: FOMC on hold, cuts IOER, ISM Miss, ADP beat, US/China Trade deal could be announced next week

* COMING UP: US jobless claims, GER retail sales (Mar), Mfg PMI (Apr/F), UK BOE/Carney, SWE Mfg PMI (Apr), AU serv/comp PMI (Apr/F), HU trade balance (Feb/F), CH Caixin Mfg PMI (Apr), India Mfg PMI (Apr), SK Mfg PMI (Apr), MEX Markit Mfg PMI (Apr), BRL Mfg PMI (Apr), Trade balance (Apr).

* WEDNESDAY’S EARNINGS: DWDP, DOW; GILD; CI

* FOMC RATE DECISION: As expected, the FOMC held the FFR at between 2.25-2.50%, though cut the IOER rate by 5bps to 2.35%. As the market was expecting, the Fed acknowledged the "solid" rate of growth (upgrading its view), while pointing out that inflation (both overall and core) has eased on a 12-month basis (now categorises it as 'below 2%'), and the central bank dropped its reference to low rates being a function of low energy prices. On the labour market, the Fed noted that job gains have been solid, though growth of household spending and business fixed investment has slowed. The decision was unanimous, and the Fed also reiterated its message of patience. On aggregate, there was not anything here that will have shocked the market.

* POWELL PRESS CONFERENCE: Fed Chair Powell attempted to navigate a neutral line in his press conference, reiterating the messages of the statement, while emphasising the appropriateness of the policy stance, and the familiar message of neutral. He added that while business fixed investment and household spending had slowed, he sees it rebounding in the months ahead. Risks have moderated since the beginning of Q1, and he noted data from China and Europe, and a disorderly Brexit has been pushed back; he also alluded to progress on trade talks with China, where the gains would be seen over time. On inflation he said the Fed strongly committed to symmetric inflation target; core inflation fall was unexpected, but likely transitory (this statement resulted in yields bounding back). Powell says the policy stance is currently appropriate and does not see the case to shift rates in either directions (the Fed chair on a few occasions reiterated that the current policy stance was appropriate); the IOER was a technical adjustment that does not represent any shift in the Fed's policy stance, and the FFR remains the central bank's main policy tool; he also said that the Fed could look at the possibility of a repo facility at upcoming meetings. Fed Chair Powell was pressed on conditions that the Fed would need to see before considering cutting rates, though he seemed reticent to be drawn into the question, and instead reiterated the Fed's policy targets. Asset prices were elevated, but not extremely so, though has some concern about corporate leverage; overall though, he does not see evidence of overheating. On the balance sheet, the FOMC had a discussion on the composition at this meeting; composition decision will need to be taken at future meetings, and any changes will be telegraphed well in advance.

* ISM MANUFACTURING PMI DATA: The index fell to a two-and-a-half year low in April, coming in at 52.8 (against an expected 55.0, from a prior 55.3). Capital Economics said that the data illustrates that, after the contraction in manufacturing output in the first quarter, US factory conditions have deteriorated further," but adds that given the recent improvement in some of the key global manufacturing data (China PMIs, Korean exports, etc.) it expects to see activity in the US manufacturing sector stabilise soon. The breakdown offered little encouragement, too. New orders fell to 51.7 from 57.4, production and employment also both sharply dropped. Inventories rose to 52.9 from 51.8, and supplier delivery times ticked slightly higher to 54.6 from 54.2, "but that was largely because demand is deteriorating even faster than production, which is hardly grounds for optimism," Capital Economics said. The consultancy notes that the alternative Markit manufacturing PMI (latest version also released today) also hit a near two-year low last month, and CapEco says that this underlines how the factory sector is struggling against a backdrop of subdued global growth, adding that "the US manufacturing data have tended to lag China's PMIs by a few months or so, with the improvement in the latter over recent months suggesting that US factory conditions should begin to stabilise soon."

* ADP EMPLOYMENT DATA: The US economy added 275k nonfarm payroll jobs in April, according to ADP, which was significantly above the 180k consensus. The prior was revised up 22k to 151k. Pantheon Macroeconomics notes that this data release is at odds with recent survey evidence which suggests current labour demand running at between 175k-200k per month. However, it says that this month's report seems to be free of obvious distortions and, as such, cannot be ignored. "The survey is not a reliable indicator of the official payroll numbers every month but the error against our ADP forecast is big enough to move the needle on our estimate for Friday's official report," the consultancy writes, "we now expect the BLS to report a 240K increase in April payrolls."

* US CONSTRUCTION SPENDING: Fell -0.9% M/M (expectations saw a flat reading). "Growth in the previous two months was revised down significantly, with spending growth in February (-0.3pp to +0.7%) and January (-1.8pp to +0.7%) now appearing much more moderate than previously reported," Goldman Sachs said, "March saw a decline in private construction spending, as residential construction (-1.8%) declined but non-residential construction increased (+0.5%). Public residential construction edged up (+0.1%) but public non-residential construction declined (-1.3%)." After the data today, Goldman Sachs' Q2 GDP tracking estimate was lowered by 0.2ppts to 1.7%

* US/CHINA TRADE: US and China have neared deal to roll-back some tariffs, Politico reports, and a deal could be announced by the end of next week. The deal reportedly includes a broad agreement on how the Trump administration will roll-back a portion of the tariffs it has imposed on more than USD 250bln-worth of Chinese goods, according sources. The two sides have also reached an understanding on how to enforce the agreement, although sources cautioned that details still need to be worked out when a Chinese delegation arrives in Washington on 8 May, Politico said. The newspaper also said that the two sides have reached general agreement on a plan for the US to immediately remove a 10% tariff on a portion of the USD 200bln worth of Chinese imports affected by the penalty, and then phase in lifting the duties on the rest of the items 'quickly,' said one of the people familiar with the discussions.

* WTI (K9) SETTLES USD 0.31 LOWER AT USD 63.60/BBL; BRENT (M9) SETTLES USD 0.17 HIGHER AT USD 72.18/BBL. Crude fell on Wednesday after DOE data echoed what was seen in the API data on Tuesday: Crude Stocks +9.934mln (Exp. 1.485mln), Cushing +0.265mln (Exp. +0.2mln), Gasoline +0.917mln (Exp. -1.005mln), Distillates-1.307mln (Exp. -0.193mln); US crude production, meanwhile, rose to a fresh record high at 12.3mln BPD. The losses seen snapped back the gains earlier in the session, amid the ongoing concerns that protests in Venezuela to pressure President Maduro to step down may put around 800k bpd of crude oil production at risk; and this explains why Brent is performing slightly better than its WTI counterpart (both are negative, though). In other news, Iranian officials agreed that its oil sales could fall to between 300-400k BPD this Summer (vs. 2.5mln BPD in May 2018), according to WSJ, which also lent some positive ticks to Brent, ahead of the weekly US inventory data. However, Iraq is reportedly planning to boost crude oil exports from its Southern port to 3.45mln BPD, newswires said. Finally, Bloomberg's OPEC survey was released on Wednesday, and analysts see OPEC crude output rising +25K BPD to 30.3mln BPD in April, as Libya's gains offset losses from sanctions against Iran; on Tuesday, the comparable Reuters survey showed analysts expected OPEC oil output to fall by 90k BPD from March to 30.23mln BPD, which would be the lowest level since 2015.

* SPX -0.8% at 2923, NDX -0.4% at 7,752, DJI -0.6% at 26,429. SECTORS: Communications -0.8%, Cons Discretionary -1.1%, Cons Staples -1.2%, Energy -2.2%, Financials -0.9%, Healthcare -0.3%, Industrials -0.8%, Materials -1.8%, Tech -0.3%, Telecoms -0.7%, Utilities -1.1%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) shares jumped higher pre-market after the iPhone maker reported earnings that beat on both top and bottom-line expectations, guided revenue higher for the next quarter and Services revenue hit record highs; boosted dividend, and announced USD 75bln share buyback. L3 Technologies (LLL) rose on strong earnings, the defence technology co. beating analyst expectations for both revenue and profits. Automatic Data Processing (ADP) opened lower after earnings missed on the top and bottom-line expectations. Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) opened higher after the chipmaker also beat analyst expectations on both top and bottom lines. Tesla (TSLA) fell throughout the session, weighed down by the news that the electric automaker would be sued by the family of a driver who had been killed in a Tesla Model X autopilot crash. CVS Health (CVS) shares jumped higher pre-market after the health care services co. reported earnings on both top and bottom lines. Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM) reported strong earnings, beating revenue expectations, but gave away pre-market gains. Humana (HUM) fell after the health insurer announced that it expects earnings to come in below the long-term EPS target of 11-15% in 2020, despite reporting a beat on both top and bottom-line expectations for Q1 19. Home Depot (HD) fell after the company’s CFO of 18 years, Carol Tome, announced her retirement.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLE 3 TICKS LOWER AT 123-18+. USTs floundered at the start of the day on thin volumes ahead of the Fed, with modest starting gains surrendered following a better than expected ADP report, with some traders noting a large block flattener of over 13k FVM9s vs over 2K ultra longs. Thereafter, however, ISM manufacturing missed at 52.8 vs. exp. 55 which added upside to the complex, with a large block buyer of 8k USM9 calls noted. The meat of the day, however, was then the Fed’s decision, which saw the curve steepening and treasuries pushing higher, with increased volumes on the front end post the unchanged rate and IOER 5bps cut to 2.35%.  Yields broke the 10th April 2.461% low, but the move was faded after Powell stated the “surprising” inflation prints could be transitory, and the IOER cut was purely “technical”. Thereafter the curve flattened and treasuries slipped to session lows heading into the close.

* FX WRAP: USD weakened throughout morning trade prior to the FOMC, largely shrugging-off a substantial ADP employment data beat, subsequently seeing downside in the aftermath of lower than expected ISM manufacturing PMI data. The move reversed during the FOMC press conference after Fed Chair Powell said the recent fall in core inflation had been unexpected and was likely transitory, reiterating that he does not see the need to shift rates in either direction, while adding that the IOER cut was purely technical; DXY hit session highs in wake of his comments. EUR, trading in thin conditions due to European market holiday closure, shrugged-off weak Manufacturing PMI data from the Netherlands and gained throughout the morning in the afterglow of yesterday’s better than expected economic data in thin. Gains vs USD were extended after weak US ISM Manufacturing PMI data, but the days move was reversed during the FOMC press conference and EURUSD finished flat at just under 1.1200. GBP maintained yesterday’s momentum against most G10 counterparts, supported by a confluence of positive drivers, which included; Markit manufacturing PMI beating expectations, positive rhetoric regarding the state of cross-party Brexit negotiations (a Labour spokesperson said there was ‘clear evidence’ that the government is prepared to explore changes to their Brexit position) and a strengthening EUR. However, the day’s gains vs USD were reversed during the FOMC press conference and, much like EURUSD, GBPUSD finished the session relatively flat at around 1.3050. JPY traded mixed vs its major G10 counterparts, initially strengthening against USD and CAD (as both nations posted weak Manufacturing PMI data) and weakening vs EUR and GBP (as the European currencies maintained some of yesterday’s momentum from positive economic data). As with EUR and GBP, gains against USD were reversed during the FOMC press conference. CAD weakened with the crude complex, the latter coming under pressure after a large headline EIA crude inventory build, and was also weighed down by weak manufacturing PMI data. NZD was unable to recoup losses induced last night in the wake of poor employment numbers (which raise the prospect of a rate cut at the RBNZ meeting next week), trading lower vs USD and AUD.

FOMC: Summary of rate decision and Powell press conference
content: As expected, the FOMC unanimously decided to hold the FFR target between 2.25-2.50%, though cut the IOER by 5bps to 2.35%. The statement saw the Fed acknowledged a "solid" rate of growth (upgrading its view, as expected), while pointing out that inflation -- both overall and core -- has eased , now downgrading its view to 'below 2%', while also dropping its reference to low rates being a function of low energy prices. The Fed noted that job gains have been solid, though growth of household spending and business fixed investment has slowed. Fed Chair Powell attempted to navigate a neutral line in his press conference, reiterating the messages of the statement, while emphasising the appropriateness of the Fed's policy stance, and the familiar message of neutral, seasoned with pateince. The Fed chair added that while business fixed investment and household spending had slowed, he sees it rebounding. Risks have moderated since the beginning of Q1, (data from China and Europe, disorderly Brexit pushed back, progress on trade talks with China, where the gains would be seen over time). Powell said the Fed was strongly committed to a symmetric inflation target; core inflation fall was unexpected, but likely transitory (this affirmation would prove to be the turning point during the presser, from a markets perspective). Powell says the policy stance is currently appropriate and does not see the case to shift rates in either directions (on a few occasions reiterating that the current policy stance was appropriate); he said the IOER was a technical adjustment that does not represent any shift in the Fed's policy stance; the FFR remains the central bank's primary policy tool; he also said that the Fed could look at the possibility of a repo facility at upcoming meetings. Fed Chair Powell was pressed on conditions that the Fed would need to see before considering cutting rates, though he seemed reticent to be drawn in, instead reiterating the Fed's policy targets. Asset prices were elevated, but not extremely so, though has some concern about corporate leverage; overall though, he does not see evidence of overheating. The FOMC had a discussion on the composition of the balance sheet; a decision will need to be taken at future meetings, and any changes will be telegraphed well in advance, Powell said.

subject: Fed's Powell says they could look at the idea of a Repo facility at an upcoming meeting

Fed Chair Powell was pressed on conditions that the Fed would need to see before considering cutting rates, though he seemed reticent to be drawn into the question, and instead reiterated the Fed's policy targets
POST FED DECISION PRESS CONFERENCE: Fed's Powell says change in IOER was technical, is not a shift in Fed policy
content:
IOER & FED FUNDS

  • Says change was technical, is not a shift in Fed policy
  • Could look at the idea of a Repo facility at an upcoming meeting
  • Small deviation outside of Fed funds target range would not be important

GROWTH

  • Sees business investment rebounding
  • Economic growth and job growth has been stronger than the committee expected
  • Expects healthy GDP growth over the rest of 2019
  • Risks abroad have moderated slightly
  • Basis for positive economic outlook is consumer spending and business investment
  • Sees no evidence of overheating

INFLATION

  • Inflation drop in early 2019 was unexpected, there might be transitory factors at work
  • Transitory factors holding down inflation could be portfolio management, apparel prices, air fares
  • If persistent low inflation is seen, they would take that into account when setting policy

REINVESTMENTS

  • Fed had prelim discussions on long-run composition of Fed's portfolio, will have to decide maturity structure

RATE PATH

  • Does not see case for moving policy in either direction
  • Data not pushing Fed in either direction

FED NOMINEES

  • Refuses to comment on potential Fed nominees

ASSETS & LEVERAGE

  • Asset prices are somewhat elevated
  • Has some concerns about corporate leverage

analysis_details: Crude fell on Wednesday after DOE data echoed what was seen in the API data on Tuesday: Crude Stocks +9.934mln (Exp. 1.485mln), Cushing +0.265mln (Exp. +0.2mln), Gasoline +0.917mln (Exp. -1.005mln), Distillates-1.307mln (Exp. -0.193mln); US crude production, meanwhile, rose to a fresh record high at 12.3mln BPD. The losses seen snapped back the gains earlier in the session, amid the ongoing concerns that protests in Venezuela to pressure President Maduro to step down may put around 800k bpd of crude oil production at risk; and this explains why Brent is performing slightly better than its WTI counterpart (both are negative, though). In other news, Iranian officials agreed that its oil sales could fall to between 300-400k BPD this Summer (vs. 2.5mln BPD in May 2018), according to WSJ, which also lent some positive ticks to Brent, ahead of the weekly US inventory data. However, Iraq is reportedly planning to boost crude oil exports from its Southern port to 3.45mln BPD, newswires said. Finally, Bloomberg's OPEC survey was released on Wednesday, and analysts see OPEC crude output rising +25K BPD to 30.3mln BPD in April, as Libya's gains offset losses from sanctions against Iran; on Tuesday, the comparable Reuters survey showed analysts expected OPEC oil output to fall by 90k BPD from March to 30.23mln BPD, which would be the lowest level since 2015.

FOMC Statement Comparison
FOMC FIRST TAKE: Rates held, IOER cut, solid growth acknowledged, soft inflation acknowledged, message of patience reiterated; all broadly as expected
reaction_details: In an immediate reaction, TNote (M9) jumped from 123-26 to 124-03, before paring; the reaction in stocks was slower, though ES (M9) eventually rose from around 2950 to around 2556; banks saw downside as the IOER was cut.
analysis_details: As expected, the FOMC held the FFR at between 2.25-2.50%, though cut the IOER rate by 5bps to 2.35%. As the market was expecting, the Fed acknolwdged the "solid" rate of growth (upgrading its view), while pointing out that inflation (both overall and core) has eased on a 12-month basis (now cataegorises it as 'below 2%'), and the central bank dropped its reference to low rates being a function of low energy prices. On the labour market, the Fed noted that job gains have been solid, though growth of household spending and business fixed investment has slowed. The decision was unanimous, and the Fed also reiterated its message of patience. On aggregate, there was not anything here that will have shocked the market.

subject: FOMC leaves rates unchanged, as expected; cuts IOER by 5bps
content:
IOER

  • Cuts interest on excess reserves rate to 2.35% from 2.40% to keep fed funds rate well within target range

INFLATION

  • Overall and core inflation have declined on a 12-month basis
  • Inflation received since March indicates economic activity has risen at a solid pace
  • Removes reference to low inflation being due to energy prices

GROWTH

  • Acknowledges pace of growth, says information received since March indicates economy has risen at a solid rate
  • Job gains have been solid, growth of household spending and business and fixed investment have slowed

FUTURE PATH

  • Reiterates patience as it determines what future adjustments to rate might be appropriate

REINVESTMENTS

  • To roll over principal payments from its holding of treasury securities that exceed USD 15bln as previously announced

VOTE SPLIT

  • Decision was unanimous

subject: PREVIEW: FOMC May 2019; decision due 1 May 2019 at 1900 BST/1400 EDT
content:
• FOMC to leave rates unchanged on 1 May (decision due 1900 BST/1400 EDT, ahead of the press conference with Chair Powell at 1930 BST/1430 EDT); The Fed will not publish new economic projections at this meeting (SEP next released in June). The market will be watching whether the Fed outlines conditions that might compel the Committee to discuss lowering rates. There are some risks that the Fed might tweak its statement to reflect stronger growth and softer inflation since the last meeting. There is also a possibility the Fed could lower its IOER rate. The Committee’s tone is likely to remain one of patience and data dependence. To download the report, please click here

US and China have neared deal to roll-back some tariffs, Politico reports, deal could be announced by the end of next week
content:
• The United States and China are closing in on a deal that includes broad agreement on how the Trump administration will roll back a portion of the tariffs it has imposed on more than USD 250bln-worth of Chinese goods, according to two people close to the talks.
  • The two sides have also reached an understanding on how to enforce the agreement, although the sources cautioned that details still need to be worked out when a Chinese delegation arrives in Washington on 8 May, Politico reports.
  • The newspaper also says the two sides have reached general agreement on a plan for the U.S. to immediately remove a 10% tariff on a portion of the USD 200bln worth of Chinese imports affected by the penalty and then phase in lifting the duties on the rest of the items “quickly,” said one of the people familiar with the discussions.

Daily FX Wrap: Greenback languishes ahead of the Fed, but Kiwi, Aussie and Loonie lag
content:
USD

Only scant comfort and impetus derived from a bumper ADP survey and upward revision to the final April manufacturing PMI as the ISM missed by some distance and components were relatively downbeat alongside considerably weaker than forecast construction spending. Moreover, the Dollar continues to err on the side of caution into the FOMC amidst dovish expectations, as aside from speculation over an IOER cut (-5 bp), with the spread to Fed Funds holding at a record 5 bp, additional pressure from President Trump has upped the ante for a further shift in the language and/or guidance from the current pause with patience towards a possible ease. However, this may be premature and Chair Powell could refrain from major changes until June when the next SEP is published and the subject of inflation targeting is discussed earlier that month – full preview of the looming FOMC available via the Research Suite and to be flagged on the headline feed nearer the event. DXY just holding the base of a 97.265-543 range and a whisker above the 30 DMA (97.216).

CHF/GBP 

The clear G10 outperformers as the Franc rebounded further from recent lows vs the Usd through 1.0150 and Cable got to within a few pips of its 55 DMA (1.3090) amidst reports that the Conservative Party has been open to compromise on Brexit demand, albeit from a Labour spox, while the Pound is also gearing up for BoE super Thursday after the impending Fed (and again a detailed primer is on the Ransquawk Research Suite).

EUR/JPY

Also gleaning momentum and making more headway at the expense of the Buck as the single currency cleared or at least peered above decent technical resistance in the form of a 61.8% Fib and 30 DMA, both at 1.1242 before topping out just shy of 1.1250, while the Yen breached its 30 DMA (111.40) more convincingly to build on yesterday’s highs and inch closer to 111.00 (at 111.14).

NZD/AUD/CAD 

All bucking the broader trend and heading into the Fed on the back foot vs their US counterpart, as the Kiwi was undermined by a downbeat Q1 NZ employment report that lifted RBNZ easing expectations to 50%+ for the May 8 policy meeting. Nzd/Usd currently hovering between 0.6678-37 parameters and the Aussie partly down in sympathy, but also in wake of a bleak CBA manufacturing PMI, with Aud/Usd hovering near the bottom of a 0.7061-35 range and Aud/Nzd back below 1.0600. Meanwhile, the Loonie lost ground following a sub-50 Canadian manufacturing PMI within a 1.3412-1.3377 band, but appeared to stave off deeper declined with the aid of comments from Canada’s Trade Minister pledging to help Canola farmers feeling the adverse effects of China’s import ban. Carr also announced plans to send delegates to Japan and South Korea in June to promote trade in the product.

NOK/SEK 

The Scandi Crowns are also under pressure, with a more pronounced pull-back in oil prices weighing on the Nok and Sek seeing contagion losses allied to bearish technical impulses. Eur/Nok cloae to 9.7200 and Eur/Sek not far from 10.6900 vs 9.6705 and 10.6425 at the other extremes respectively.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 1st May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Markets have been quiet due to the mass closures for Labour Day, while the FTSE 100 (+0.1%) is similarly uninspiring
  • In FX sterling outperforms but the broadly in line PMI did little for the currency, while NZD underperforms following the weak jobs data
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US ADP & Construction Spending, US ISM Manufacturing PMI, FOMC Rate Decision & Press Conference, BoC's Wilkins and Poloz
  • Earnings: CVS, Qualcomm. CME Group, Automatic Data Processing, GlaxoSmithKline
  • Note: Market Closures for European and Chinese Labour Day Holiday

ASIA-PAC

A quiet tone was observed in Asia-Pacific amid closures in nearly all the major regional bourses for Labour Day, although US equity futures were underpinned after-hours following Apple earnings in which the tech giant beat on top and bottom lines, authorized an additional USD 75bln share repurchase and raised its dividends by 5%. ASX 200 (+0.8%) was positive with the index led higher by tech on contagion from Nasdaq futures and with financials buoyed as ANZ shares rallied nearly 3% after its H1 results, while reports that the US dropped a key demand regarding cyber theft in an effort to accelerate a trade deal with China also added to the optimism although most of the region failed to capitalize with China, Hong Kong, India, Japan, Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan all shut.

US White House reportedly dropped a key demand regarding cyber theft in an effort to accelerate a trade deal with China. (FT)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and USTR Lighthizer have concluded their 'productive' meetings with China's Vice Premier He, talks are to continue in Washington next week. (Twitter)

US

US Senator Ernst said she would be a no on Stephen Moore for the Fed at this point and that she doesn't think Stephen Moore would be approved for the Fed board seat if the vote was held today, while Senator Graham also commented that Steven Moore's nomination would be very problematic. (Newswires)

US Special Counsel Mueller told AG Barr that his summary on the Special Counsel report caused confusion and missed the essence of the report. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICAL

Venezuela’s Maduro declared victory against a coup of plotters and said armed forces had defeated a small group. There were also reports that Venezuela's Guaido called on the military and civilians to conduct fresh mass protests on Wednesday, while the FAA ordered US air operators to not fly below 26K feet over Venezuela amid political instability and tensions. (Newswires)

US President Trump threatened Cuba with sanctions and embargo over actions in Venezuela, while US Secretary of State Pompeo said US had indications Venezuela's Maduro was ready to leave the country on Tuesday morning but Russian President Putin convinced him to stay, however, Russia and Maduro have denied these claims. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM May is said to have blocked a cabinet attempt to speed up the Brexit process this week with Downing Street overruling Brexiteer ministers that had expected a withdrawal agreement bill to be brought before the commons, while reports noted that PM May is concerned MPs could vote down the bill at the first attempt and potentially trigger a general election. (Huffington Post)

Eurosceptic ministers fear that PM May is preparing to give in to Labour demands on Brexit after they were told an unpalatable result would be better than a disastrous one. (Telegraph)

UK Opposition Labour Party sources suggest there are no cross-party Brexit talks scheduled for today, and given local elections tomorrow, they suspect "nothing this week", according to Sky News' Cohen. (Twitter)

Times’ Shadow Monetary Policy Committee unanimously believe the BoE should hold interest rates this week because the political backdrop is too uncertain to change policy. (Times)

ECB's VP de Guindos (Neutral) says the structurally low profitability of the euro area banking sector remains a concern for financial stability and for monetary policy. The low interest rate environment is with us for the foreseeable future and is caused in large part by durable structural factors, adds that the ECB is open-minded regarding tweaks to the target, adding that officials are yet to discuss changing the target. (Newswires)

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 53.1 vs. Exp. 53.0 (Prev. 55.1)

- New export business declines

- Stock-building continues at solid, yet slower, pace

EQUITIES

Mass closures in Europe have extended the quiet tone seen across Asia, with only UK and Danish markets open today in the EU. The FTSE 100 (-0.1%) is relatively flat with sectors also showing no clear standouts. In terms of movers, Sainsbury’s (+4.7%) rose to the top of the index amidst optimistic revenue and profit numbers, alongside a net debt reduction which is ahead of target. To the downside, Persimmon (-1.8%) shares suffer after fire issues were found in houses developed by the company, the company is addressing the issue. State-side, Apple reported earnings aftermarket wherein the tech giant topped estimates on both top and bottom line, whilst Q3 guidance was also above analyst consensus, despite a sharp drop in Q2 iPhone sales. Apple shares spiked higher in excess of 5% post-earnings.

Apple (AAPL) Q2 EPS USD 2.46 vs. Exp. USD 2.36, rev. USD 58.02bln vs. Exp. USD 57.37bln. (Newswires) - Co. authorized additional USD 75bln for share buybacks and raised dividend 5% to USD 0.77. - iPhone net sales USD 31.05bln vs Prev. USD 37.56bln. - iPad net sales USD 4.87bln vs. Prev.  USD 4.01bln. - Mac net sales USD 5.51bln vs. Prev. USD 5.78bln. - Sees Q3 revenue between USD 52.5bln-54.5bln.vs. Exp. USD 52.4bln.

- For reference, Co. were around 5% higher in after market trade

FX

GBP/NZD - Flanking the G10 ranks at the start of the new month, as Cable extends gains through more chart resistance levels on the way to circa 1.3073, like the 30 DMA (1.3052), a Fib (1.3053) and daily tech formation (1.3065), eyeing 1.3090 next (55 DMA) before the 1.3100 handle. A broadly in line and less stockpile-inflated UK manufacturing PMI amidst mixed BoE mortgage and consumer data was largely shrugged off, but Sterling also eked more upside vs the Euro as the cross eased a bit further below 0.8600 to test bids just ahead of a 50% retracement (0.8583) following more reports about constructive cross party Brexit talks as discussions are put on hold due to Thursday’s local elections. More immediately, focus on the Fed before the BoE tomorrow – see the Ransquawk headline feed for detailed previews of the 2 events. Conversely, weaker than forecast NZ jobs data has raised the stakes in terms of RBNZ rate cut expectations for next week and Nzd/Usd retreated in response through 0.6650, as the Aud/Nzd cross rebounded firmly from around 1.0560 to just over 1.0600. However, the Kiwi has pared some losses since with the probability of an ease still close enough to 50% for reasonable doubt.

CHF - Another major outperformer or rather beneficiary of a deeper pull-back in the Dollar ahead of the FOMC, as the Franc edges towards 1.0150 and DXY slips to 97.359, very close to a 97.355 Fib and nearer the 30 DMA (97.216).

AUD/EUR - Also firmer vs the Greenback as Aud/Usd consolidates recovery gains around 0.7050 and the single currency builds a foothold above 1.1200. Eur/Usd has eclipsed Fib resistance at 1.1217 and is now approaching convergence at 1.1242 (another Fib and 30 DMA) before 1.1250 and 1.1275 (latter roughly coincides with the 50 DMA).

 

JPY/CAD - Both narrowly mixed vs the Usd, as the Yen attempts to breach the 30 DMA (111.40) and retest Tuesday’s peaks, while the Loonie continues its recovery from yesterday’s post-Canadian GDP lows within a 1.3400-1.3375 range in advance of the manufacturing PMI and more from BoC’s Poloz and Wilkins.

 

New Zealand Employment Change (Q1) Q/Q -0.2% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires) New Zealand Unemployment Rate (Q1) 4.2% vs. Exp. 4.2% (Prev. 4.3%) New Zealand Participation Rate (Q1) 70.4% vs. Exp. 70.9% (Prev. 70.9%) New Zealand Labour Cost Index (Q1) Q/Q 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.5%)

 

FIXED INCOME

Pre-UK data and PMI price activity suggests some front-running or hedging for a bigger than forecast retracement in manufacturing activity, as the 10 year benchmark squeezed up to a new 127.41 Liffe intraday high (+9 ticks vs -10 ticks at worst), but then eased back on the release that was a smidge better than anticipated in the event. However, survey sub-components were less resilient after premature Brexit stock-building given the extended Article 50 deadline to October 31, and Gilts retain an underlying bid in keeping with USTs ahead of ADP, manufacturing PMI and ISM amidst various holidays that are weighing on turnover.

COMMODITIES

The energy market had a stellar performance in April as the benchmarks climbed over 6% amidst intensifying tensions in Venezuela, tightening US sanctions on Iran and ongoing OPEC supply cuts. Ahead of the end of Iranian oil waivers later, oil Journalist Reza Zandi notes that Iranian officials are reportedly discussing three potential Iranian scenarios in OPEC:  1) Iran suspends its membership in OPEC until sanctions are removed, 2) Iran departs from OPEC and 3) Iran continues its membership. In today’s trade, oil prices have reversed a bulk of the April gains following a much wider-than-forecast build in API crude stockpiles (6.8mln vs. Exp. 1.5mln), marking the 4th stock build in April. PVM analysts also highlight the uptrend in US stockpiles which is described as a “deepening pocket of weakness” amid a host of a bullish catalysts. WTI and Brent futures have thus retreated back below/around USD 64/bbl and USD 72/bbl respectively ahead of today’s EIA data wherein the market is geared for a headline build of 1.485mln barrels.  Elsewhere, gold remains within a relatively tight range around 1280/oz ahead of the FOMC rate decision (preview available in the Research Suite) whilst copper mirrors the humdrum tone with most the region away on holiday. Finally, aluminium prices remain pressured following on from the weaker-than-forecast Chinese manufacturing data coupled with producers revising down their demand growth estimates for the year.

Abu Dhabi have launched a second bid round for 5 major exploration blocks which have substantial oil and gas potential., according to an ADNOC statement. (Newswires)

Tanker Trackers report that they are "currently following up on a lead of a POSSIBLE incident involving not one, but two Iranian tankers sailing in parallel in the Red Sea. One of them is said to be leaking". (Twitter)

content: Shrugging off or ignoring pretty neutral US leads, Gilts have retreated a bit further from Tuesday’s recovery highs after a slightly firmer start and fleeting uptick to 127.35 vs yesterday’s Liffe close with a low subsequently posted at 127.22. The Short Sterling strip is also on the defensive between 0.5 and 2 ticks below previous settlement levels in contrast to the firmer tone in UK stocks and the Pound as the FTSE is underpinned by some individual names rather than the usual inverse equity vs currency correlation. Ahead, a busy domestic agenda features BoE consumer and mortgage lending figures and the manufacturing PMI as the clock ticks down to the FOMC and BoE super Thursday. Back to Liffe, and from a technical standpoint 127.00-50 provide the obvious nearest support and resistance inside chart levels of 126.94 and 127.72 (Tuesday’s intraday base and apex).

content:
Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) – FY19 revenue GBP 29.01bln vs. Exp. GBP 28.98bln, underlying profit before tax GBP 635mln vs. Exp. GBP 626.8mln. Final dividend of 7.9 pence per share. Co. state that net debt is GBP 222mn lower, which is ahead of the target. Co. state that their outlook remains uncertain and they are investing in order to improve over 400 supermarkets this year. (Newswires)

Next (NXT LN) – Q1 retail sales -3.6% vs. Exp. -6.2%, online sales +11.8% vs. Exp. +12.8%. Co. state that it is too soon to revise FY sales and profit guidance, as FY sales for Q1 were +4.5% vs. Exp. +3.2%, stating that this was due to the Easter periods’ warm weather. (Newswires)

Lloyds (LLOY LN) – Co. have revised their capital guidance, notifying that there systemic risk buffer for the Co’s ring fenced bank will be 200bps, which equals 170bps at the group level below the prior 210bps. Level of CET1 capital targeted has reduced to 13% vs. Prev. 12.5%. (Newswires)

Inmarsat (ISAT LN) – Q1 revenue USD 346.9mln, +0.4%. Q1 EBOTDA USD 152.4mln, -12.9%. Co. reiterates their guidance which is unchanged from March (Newswires)

Provident Financial (PFG LN) – Co. state that Non-Standard Finance (NSF LN) have failed to respond to central questions referring to their offer, Co’s board believes that the announcement from Non-Standard falls short of providing a satisfactory response to Co. shareholders; continue to believe the offer undervalues the Co. (Newswires)

London Stock Exchange (LSE LN) – Q1 revenue GBP 214mln, +6.0%. Q1 total revenue from continuing operations GBP 486mln vs. Prev. GBP 470mln. Co. state they are well placed strategically to develop growth opportunities further in evolving the macroeconomic landscape. (Newswires)

Sainsbury's (SBRY LN) - Co’s CEO states that their business can adapt to the retail world without Asda (Newswires)

Ashtead Group (ASH LN) – Co. have appointed Lindsey Ruth as a non-executive director with immediate effect. (Newswires)

Persimmon (PSN LN) – Co. state they continue to anticipate that overall build costs will increase by around 4% for the year. Co. state that revenue from upcoming sales has been lower for the year so far. (Newswires)

Orsted (ORSTED DC) – Q1 EBITDA DKK 5.1bln vs. Prev. DKK 5.5bln, Co. states that their FY guidance is unchanged and they started the year well. Co. have submitted bids for offshore wind schemes in France, Netherlands and the US; and they continue to anticipate the signing of divestment of Danish Power Distribution business towards the end of the year. (Newswires)

BASF (BASF GY) – Co. and Letterone have completed the merger of Wintersall and DEA, Co. state that expect to realise annual synergies of at a minimum EUR 200mln by the third year following the transactions competition. Separately, Co. state they are on tract to achieve production target of 750-850k OEBPD between 2021-2023. (Newswires)

Pearson (PSON LN) – McGraw-Hill and Cengage are planning a merger with the joint Co. to hold around USD 3.16bln in annual revenue. (WSJ/Newswires)

RBS (RBS LN) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM OUTPERFORM AT KBW

PRYSMIAN (PRY IM) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT CITI

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

1st May 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

Note: Euronext, Eurex, FTSE MIB, Bolsa de Madrid, SMI, Oslo Børs, OMX are all closed for the European Labour Day Holiday on the 1st May 2019.

ASIA

A quiet tone was observed in Asia-Pacific amid closures in nearly all the major regional bourses for Labour Day, although US equity futures were underpinned after-hours following Apple earnings in which the tech giant beat on top and bottom lines, authorized an additional USD 75bln share repurchase and raised its dividends by 5%. ASX 200 (+0.8%) was also positive with the index led higher by tech on contagion from Nasdaq futures and with financials buoyed as ANZ shares rallied nearly 3% after its H1 results, while reports that the US dropped a key demand regarding cyber theft in an effort to accelerate a trade deal with China also added to the optimism although most of the region failed to capitalize with China, Hong Kong, India, Japan, Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan all shut.

FTSE

BP (BP/ LN) – Gambia’s government says it has agreed a contract with the Co. to explore offshore oil and gas. (Newswires)

Persimmon (PSN LN)/Bellway (BWY LN) – Houses developed by the two Co’s reportedly have potentially dangerous fire issues, as new builds by the Co’s were sold with missing or improperly fitted fire barriers. The two Co’s state they are addressing the issue. (BBC)

Tesco (TSCO LN) – Co. has reportedly asked the UK government to instigate a 2% online sales tax, in order to assist in funding for a reduction in business rates for shops as the Co. states the current system is unfair and damaging to communities. (Guardian)

Rio Tinto (RIO LN) – Co’s CEO stated on CNBC that their order books for copper, as well as other minerals, are ‘absolutely full’, adding that Brexit is of no concern to the Co. and he firmly believes that US and China will reach a trade deal. (Newswires)

British American Tobacco (BATS LN) – FDA has placed stringent marketing restrictions on heated tobacco products which is aimed at preventing youth access and limiting their exposure to new products. FDA have also permitted the sale of Phillip Morris's (PM) IQO’s heated tobacco products. (Newswires/FT) Following this announcement shares in Phillip Morris (PM) and Altria (MO) spiked higher. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

JUST EAT (JE/ LN) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERWEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN

STANDARD CHARTERED (STAN LN) DOWNGRADED TO REDUCE FROM HOLD AT HSBC

BP (BP/LN) REITERATED OUTPERFROM AT RBC

DAX

Deutsche Lufthansa (LHA GY) – Co. state that foreign shareholders have now reached 40%, and the Co. does not intend to buy back shares. (Newswires)

Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) – DOJ antitrust chief Delrahim says Sprint’s (S) precarious financial position is a factor in potential approval of merger with T Mobile (TMUS), and the DOJ is looking at 'failing firm defence' as part of deal review, Fox reports. (Fox) For reference, the Co. holds 63.04% of T-Mobile shares.

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

DWS (DWS GY) – Co. has reduced its UK headcount by around 5%, according to reports. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

DEUTSCHE BANK (DBK GY) RESUMED WITH UNDERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

COMMERZBANK (CBK GY) RESUMED WITH EQUALWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

PUMA (PUM GY) REITERATED UNDERPERFORM AT RBC

CAC

Energy Names – France are to delay the shutdown of some of their nuclear power industry in order to assist French President Macron’s target of making France carbon-neutral by 2050. (FT)

Pernod Ricard (RI FP) – Co. has hired banks to find a suitor for its strategic wine brands portfolio, according to reports. (AFR)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Red Electrica (REE SM) – Q1 EBITDA EUR 405.9mln vs. Exp. EUR 405mln, revenue EUR 499.7mln vs. Prev. EUR 497mln and net EUR 191mln vs. Prev. EUR 189.1mln. (Newswires)

Aena (AENA SM) – Q1 EBITDA EUR 393mln vs. Exp. EUR 383mln, revenue EUR 904mln vs. Prev. EUR 842mln and net EUR 136.4mln vs. Exp. EUR 136mln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

FERRAGAMO (SFER IM) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM HOLD AT JEFFERIES

SMI

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA 

GN Store Nord (GN DC) – Q1 revenue DKK 2.84bln vs. Exp. DKK 2.89bln, EBITA DKK 439mln vs. Exp. DKK 486mln. Co. state that their FY19 guidance, which they upgraded on 12th April, is still accurate. Co. add that their innovation strategy is working as planned as they had a strong start to FY19. Co. announce a DKK 1bln share buyback. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

US

USD 37.56bln. - iPad net sales USD 4.87bln vs. Prev.  USD 4.01bln. - Mac net sales USD 5.51bln vs. Prev. USD 5.78bln. - Sees Q3 revenue between USD 52.5bln-54.5bln.vs. Exp. USD 52.4bln. For reference, the Co. were around 5% higher in after market trade.

Advanced Micro Devices Inc (AMD) adj. EPS 0.06 (exp. 0.05), Revenue 1.27bln (exp. 1.26bln) Sees Q2 revenue at USD 1.52bln (exp. 1.52bln), computing and graphics segment was down 26% YY and 16% QQ. (Newswires) For reference, the Co. were around 4% higher in after market trade.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 1st May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • A quiet tone was observed in Asia-Pacific amid market closures, US equity futures were underpinned after-hours following Apple earnings
  • Eurosceptic ministers fear that PM May is preparing to give in to Labour demands on Brexit after they were told an unpalatable result would be better than a disastrous one
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK Manufacturing PMI, US ADP & Construction Spending, US ISM Manufacturing PMI, FOMC Rate Decision & Press Conference, ECB's de Guindos, BoC's Wilkins and Poloz
  • Earnings: CVS, Qualcomm. CME Group, Automatic Data Processing, GlaxoSmithKline
  • Note: Market Closures for European and Chinese Labour Day Holiday

ASIA-PAC

A quiet tone was observed in Asia-Pacific amid closures in nearly all the major regional bourses for Labour Day, although US equity futures were underpinned after-hours following Apple earnings in which the tech giant beat on top and bottom lines, authorized an additional USD 75bln share repurchase and raised its dividends by 5%. ASX 200 (+0.8%) was also positive with the index led higher by tech on contagion from Nasdaq futures and with financials buoyed as ANZ shares rallied nearly 3% after its H1 results, while reports that the US dropped a key demand regarding cyber theft in an effort to accelerate a trade deal with China also added to the optimism although most of the region failed to capitalize with China, Hong Kong, India, Japan, Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan all shut.

US White House reportedly dropped a key demand regarding cyber theft in an effort to accelerate a trade deal with China. (FT)

US Agricultural Secretary Perdue said he doesn't want it implied 'a deal is done' with China but said he remains cautiously optimistic about the prospects of reaching a deal. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM May is said to have blocked a cabinet attempt to speed up the Brexit process this week with Downing Street overruling Brexiteer ministers that had expected a withdrawal agreement bill to be brought before the commons, while reports noted that PM May is concerned MPs could vote down the bill at the first attempt and potentially trigger a general election. (Huffington Post)

Eurosceptic ministers fear that PM May is preparing to give in to Labour demands on Brexit after they were told an unpalatable result would be better than a disastrous one. (Telegraph)

UK opposition Labour Party rejected the idea of campaigning for a referendum under all circumstances but agreed to support a 2nd Brexit referendum if it cannot secure a general election or the government will not change policy. (Newswires)

Times’ Shadow Monetary Policy Committee unanimously believe the BoE should hold interest rates this week because the political backdrop is too uncertain to change policy. (Times)

ECB's Lane (Dove) said it is not true that the ECB is out of options and that fiscal policy can have a role in reducing uncertainty and encouraging the private sector to start investing. (Newswires)

UK BRC Shop Price Index (Apr) Y/Y 0.4% (Prev. 0.9%). (Newswires)

FX

 

FX price action was mostly restrained by the holiday-thinned conditions which kept the greenback around the 97.50 level after the prior day’s losses against its counterparts across the pond, in which EUR/USD reclaimed the 1.1200 handle following better than expected GDP for Q1 and with GBP/USD back above the 1.3000 level. US President Trump also weighed in on the Fed once again as he stated that they incessantly lifted interest rates despite low inflation and suggested the US economy could rocket if the Fed were to reduce rates by a point, while focus shifts to the upcoming FOMC meeting where UBS expects a further dovish shift by the Fed. Elsewhere, antipodeans were mixed as AUD/USD meandered around the 0.7050 level and with NZD/USD the underperformer after a miss on Q1 Employment and Wage data which resulted in markets pricing in a 56% probability for the RBNZ to cut rates next week vs. Prev. 40% chances the prior day.

New Zealand Employment Change (Q1) Q/Q -0.2% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires) New Zealand Unemployment Rate (Q1) 4.2% vs. Exp. 4.2% (Prev. 4.3%) New Zealand Participation Rate (Q1) 70.4% vs. Exp. 70.9% (Prev. 70.9%) New Zealand Labour Cost Index (Q1) Q/Q 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.5%)

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mostly rangebound overnight as a lack of participants and pre-FOMC tentativeness kept demand lacklustre with WTI crude futures firmly below the USD 64.00/bbl level after the prior day’s choppy action and larger than expected build to headline API crude inventories. Gold prices were subdued and failed to benefit from a weaker greenback as markets lay in wait for the Fed meeting later and Friday’s US jobs data, while copper mirrored the humdrum tone across asset classes with most the region away for holiday.

US API weekly crude stocks (22 Apr, w/e) 6.8M vs. Exp. 1.5M (Prev. 6.9M). (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Venezuela’s Maduro declared victory against a coup of plotters and said armed forces had defeated a small group. There were also reports that Venezuela's Guaido called on the military and civilians to conduct fresh mass protests on Wednesday, while the FAA ordered US air operators to not fly below 26K feet over Venezuela amid political instability and tensions. (Newswires)

 

US President Trump threatened Cuba with sanctions and embargo over actions in Venezuela, while US Secretary of State Pompeo said US had indications Venezuela's Maduro was ready to leave the country on Tuesday morning but Russian President Putin convinced him to stay, however, Russia and Maduro have denied these claims. (Newswires)

US

The Treasury complex was ticking lower after overnight Chinese PMI data remained in expansion (not a spectacular print, but continues to point to stabilisation), and then EZ growth surprising to the upside slightly saw the complex find lows. However, the trend soon reversed, the complex moving higher after Chicago PMI missed the forecast range, which doesn't augur particularly well for the upcoming ISM reports (even though the data may have been influenced heavily by Boeing's woes) and the 2 and 3 year yields reached fresh 1-month lows. Some desks also suggested month-end factors were playing a role in the Treasury action. US T-note futures (M9) settled 7+ ticks higher at 123-21+.

US President Trump said the Federal Reserve has incessantly lifted interest rates even though inflation is very low and instituted a very big dose of quantitative tightening, while he believes the US economy could 'go up like a rocket' if the Fed were to reduce rates by 1 point. (Newswires)

US Senator Ernst said she would be a no on Stephen Moore for the Fed at this point and that she doesn't think Stephen Moore would be approved for the Fed board seat if the vote was held today, while Senator Graham also commented that Steven Moore's nomination would be very problematic. (Newswires)

US Speaker of the House Pelosi said there has been an agreement with US President Trump on a USD 2tln package for infrastructure. (Newswires)

US Special Counsel Mueller told AG Barr that his summary on the Special Counsel report caused confusion and missed the essence of the report. (Newswires)

Apple (AAPL) Q2 EPS USD 2.46 vs. Exp. USD 2.36, rev. USD 58.02bln vs. Exp. USD 57.37bln. (Newswires) - Co. authorized additional USD 75bln for share buybacks and raised dividend 5% to USD 0.77. - iPhone net sales USD 31.05bln vs Prev. USD 37.56bln. - iPad net sales USD 4.87bln vs. Prev.  USD 4.01bln. - Mac net sales USD 5.51bln vs. Prev. USD 5.78bln. - Sees Q3 revenue between USD 52.5bln-54.5bln.vs. Exp. USD 52.4bln.
